items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the continued high tide forecast peaking at 10:45 AM today, 08/11/2022.
Flooding is possible at Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods between 10:00 AM and 12:00 PM on 08/11/2022.
The next high tide is expected to be higher than normal on 08/11/2022 at 11:00 PM and may result in us issuing a further alert.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Please be careful along low lying land, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 08/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising steadily on Derwentwater lake level due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and  Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout today.
River levels are expected to peak at 1.96m at 11:00am on Tuesday 08/11/2022 at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 6:00pm on 08/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Flooding is affecting locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water with lake levels peaking around 11:00am on Tuesday 08/11/2022. Derwentwater lake levels at the Lodore gauge could reach 1.96 this morning. We are clearing debris in the area and we will continue to monitor the forecast and issue warnings if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00am on Wednesday 09/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. Highest tide level is expected to be at 10:45am on Tuesday 08/11/2022. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time. Sandside is the area most at risk but wave overtopping could also be seen at low lying around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Arnside and Silverdale. No property flooding is expected. The high tides later today - are also expected to be higher than normal and are likely to result in us issuing further alerts. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Tuesday 08/11/2022.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Tuesday evening's tide between 17:45 and 19:45 on 08/11/2022 is expected to cause localised flooding due to wind and wave action. Areas most at risk include exposed areas near the Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall including Kilnsea village. There are spring tides this week with the highest of these on Tuesday 08/11/2022 and Wednesday 09/11/2022. Unsettled conditions are expected, however no large surge is forecast. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 08/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: This flood alert has been removed. High tides are currently below levels of concern. However, these tides will still require caution and we may need to re-issue this alert due to spring tides and unsettled conditions on Wednesday 09/11/2022. Please take care on promenades and coastal roads. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
Although more rain is forecast for today, no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This flood alert has been removed. High tides on Tuesday 8th November and Wednesday 9th November are below levels of concern. However, these tides will still require caution. Please take care on promenades and coastal roads. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast this evening and tomorrow morning. The first forecast high water is at 21:25 PM on 08/11/2022 with a level of 1.29 mAODN with westerly force 6 winds. The second forecast high water is at 09:43 AM on 09/11/2022 with a level of 1.20 mAODN with westerly force 5 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). Areas most at risk are Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Rivers Avon and Stour. All flood gates have been closed.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 09/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tides and strong winds forecast.
Areas most at risk include Castletown, Weymouth, Preston Beach, Swanage Bay, Studland Bay, Sandbanks, Poole Harbour, Bournemouth Beach, Hengistbury Head and Christchurch Harbour.
The high tides along the coast will be between 18:43 and 21:25 - for more info refer to local tide tables
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 09/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Upper Wey, especially the Godalming area as a result of the recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is expected today and tomorrow 09/11/22.
The forecast for today is for further showers, which could be heavy this afternoon. Levels will continue to fall but stay above the flood alert level.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening 08/11/22, or if the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have risen slightly overnight following heavy rainfall, but the risk of localised flooding has now passed.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further showers are forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain above the Alert threshold on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of the recent rain. Therefore, flooding of low-lying roads and farmland is still possible, especially in the Free Prae Road area. 
The forecast for today is for some light showers, with a dry day tomorrow and Thursday. Levels continue to fall but remain above flood alert for the coming days.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 08/11/22, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday evening. High water at Exmouth is at 18:45 hours, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 6 South Westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 1.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be up to 330mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level on Tuesday evening at Exmouth is 2.38 mAOD, this is 0.33 metres above the astronomical tide level.

The Flood Alert for Beadnell Harbour Road (north) and Newbiggin Bay Promenade (north) has now been removed. There is no longer risk to beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as wave overtopping and spray has reduced. We continue to monitor the situation.
The forecast tide level is now lowering. As the weather transitions to a more settled outlook over the next 24 hours, no further impacts are currently expected.

The forecast tide level is now lowering. As moderate wave heights are forecast this evening (Tuesday 8/11/22 at 23:00) some very minor residual impacts may occur at high tide tonight and possibly tomorrow morning (11:30 on 09/11/22). After this time, the weather transitions to a more settled outlook and further impacts are not currently expected.

The forecast tide level is now lowering. As moderate wave heights are forecast this evening (Tuesday 8/11/22 at 22:40) some spray overtopping could affect roads or footpaths on exposed sections of the coastline. After this time, the weather transitions to a more settled outlook, and further impacts are not currently expected.
As the weather transitions to a more settled outlook over the next 24 hours, forecast tide levels are now reducing, and no further impacts are expected.

The forecast tide level is now lowering, and only a small amount of rain is expected today and tomorrow (Wednesday 9 November 2022).  As the weather transitions to a more settled outlook, no further impacts are currently expected.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have risen slightly overnight following heavy rainfall, but the risk of localised flooding has now passed.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further showers are forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have remained below the flood risk threshold.    Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have remained below the flood risk threshold.    Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Tuesday, 8/11/22. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further showers are forecast throughout today, 8/11/22, and tomorrow morning, 09/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Please refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Wednesday, 9/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are still higher than normal in Isfield, but all along the River Uck water levels are now falling and are significantly lower than recent days. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads could continue until Wednesday afternoon, when the River Uck should be nearer to normal. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. However, scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message: River levels remain high but are falling gradually at Forest Row, Summerford Bridge, near Withyham and at Colliers land Bridge near Ashurst. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Tuesday 8 November 2022, and a rise in river levels may be seen. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly around Forest Row, Ashurst and Penshurst and around Balls Green at Ashurst. We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. This message will be updated by 10pm on Tuesday 8 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is still high but is slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and riverside properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury, but will reduce Tuesday. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. However, scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. The River Adur is unlikely to return to nearer normal until Wednesday (09/11/2022). Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

The water level in the Eastern Yar remains higher than normal, but at Alverstone and Sandown, the level continues to slowly fall by 1cm per hour. Since midnight, only 5mm of rain has been recorded at Wroxall. Today (Tuesday 8/11/22) some minor impact flooding of roads (including Golf Links and Moreton Common Road), and land is still expected. Showers are forecast from around 14:00 today and these will continue overnight and into tomorrow (Wednesday 9/11/22). Whilst these showers may cause an increase in water level, it is currently unlikely that the totals forecast (10-20mm) will flood property. Additional rainfall will however increase flood impacts on land, roads and possibly to gardens. From Thursday (10/11/22) onwards, the weather is forecast to be dry and so towards the end of the week, the situation will finally improve. We continue to monitor the forecast. We are operating Bembridge sluice to help manage water levels at Brading Marshes. Please avoid walking, driving or cycling through ponded water.  This Flood Alert will be updated by 14:00 on Wednesday 09/11/22.

The River Ouse is significantly lower than its peaks of recent days, and is continuing to slowly fall all along its length. Flooding affecting properties should ease at Barcombe Mills. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads along most of the Upper Ouse, including at Sloop Lane, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge should reduce by Wednesday. Barcombe Mills Road could still be impassable. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. However, scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 on Tuesday 08/11/2022.

River levels are still high in Alfriston but are falling. Flooding will continue to affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. River levels in Alfriston will continue to slowly fall but will remain higher than normal until at least Thursday. In Hellingly, both the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers have fallen significantly from their peak and will continue falling Tuesday. Minor flood impacts should continue to reduce at Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. However, scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding in Hellingly and Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high at locations in the Rother valley but are starting to fall slowly. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Tuesday 8 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area, around Shrub Lane and along the River Rother, particularly around Robertsbridge. We are ready to use the flood defence scheme at Robertsbridge if required. We are continuing to monitor the situation, and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. This message will be updated by 10pm on Tuesday 8 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high in the Leatherhead and Cobham areas. The risk of flooding to roads and low lying land remains throughout today 8/11/2022. Further light rainfall is expected today. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please remain aware of your local situation. This message will be updated by 05:00pm on Wednesday 8/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is still high but is slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and riverside properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury, but will reduce Tuesday. However, there remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. Scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. The River Adur is unlikely to return to nearer normal until Wednesday (09/11/2022). Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for showers through today, Tuesday 8th November, but drier for the rest of the week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high but are falling gradually at locations between Yalding and Allington Lock, including Maidstone. Internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Tuesday 8 November 2022, but no further river level rise is expected. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly riverside areas of Maidstone and along the River Medway. We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. This message will be updated by 10pm on Tuesday 8 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

Both the Bull River and Cuckmere River in Hellingly have fallen significantly from their peak of recent days. We expect river levels to continue to fall Tuesday. Minor flood impacts should continue to reduce at Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly. However, there remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. Scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Some roads may be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Station Road, Church Lane, Church Road and Mill Lane, Hellingly. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

The River Ouse is still high in Barcombe, but continues to fall. Flooding affecting properties, should ease at Barcombe Mills and the Anchor Inn. Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane may still be impassable. Flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads should reduce by Wednesday. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. However, scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Please keep flood protection products installed in Barcombe, if you have them, as a precaution. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 on Tuesday 08/11/2022.

The Cuckmere River in Alfriston is still high but is falling. Flooding will continue to affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Tuesday and Wednesday. However, we predict river levels in Alfriston will continue to fall, although the Cuckmere River will remain higher than normal until the end of the week. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on Tuesday 08/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: Following further heavy rainfall yesterday, river levels remain high but are falling gradually in Edenbridge, Hever, Vexour, Lingfield and Haxted Mill areas. The internal flooding of property is not expected. Patchy rain is forecast today, Tuesday 8 November 2022 but no further river level rise is expected. Please avoid using low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. We are continuing to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the rivers. This message will be updated by 10pm on Tuesday 8 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The forecast for tonight is for light showers but will be drier for the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

The Western Rother is still very high at Fittleworth but is now slowly falling. Water will be very close to Fittleworth Mill and nearby properties. The river will be higher than normal at Fittleworth most of the week. At Lodsbridge near Selham, the river is high but slowly falling. Water will be very close to properties at Lodsbridge until Tuesday afternoon (08/11/2022). Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak, and only minor flood impacts are expected. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. However, scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please keep property flood resilience measures installed at Lodsbridge, near Selham, and Fittleworth, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on Tuesday 08/11/2022.

The Langney Haven is high and rising over each high tide. The next tides are at 11:00 and 23:00 Tuesday 08/11/2022. Flooding could affect gardens of Langney Green, and potentially approaching properties at Langney Green too. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park could also be affected. Wednesday's peak water level could be 20cm higher than we've seen so far in recent days. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. Scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to also cause another small rise in river levels. River levels might not return nearer to normal until next week, 16/11/2022. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed, at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

River levels are slowly falling in Crowhurst and Bulverhythe, and are forecast to continue falling Tuesday. However, there remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. It is possible the scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday could cause another small rise in river levels. If a shower in the Crowhurst area is particularly intense, flood water could possibly approach a small number of riverside properties in Crowhurst, on Forewood Lane and between the Plough public house and Sandrock Hill. However, we feel it is more likely the river should now slowly fall, with river levels in Crowhurst returning nearer to normal by Wednesday (09/11/2022). River levels in Bulverhythe could stay higher than normal until the end of the week, but only minor flood impacts affecting Bexhill Road Recreation Ground are currently predicted. Please keep flood protection products installed in Crowhurst, if you have them, as a precaution. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

Tuesday evening's tide at 23:15 on 08/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.12 m. The total forecast tide is 5.99 metres Chart Datum (2.94 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Minor flood impacts are expected over Wednesday morning's tide too, peaking at 11:30 09/11/2022. From Thursday tides and waves are predicted to be smaller. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 09:00 on 09/11/2022.

The River Arun is still high and slowly rising, at Pallingham Lock, but should begin to fall by Tuesday afternoon. Between Horsham and Wanford, river levels are now significantly lower than their recent peak, and falling. However, all along the Upper Arun, minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens, rural roads and isolated mill properties, will continue. Possibly until Thursday. There remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. Scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please keep flood protection products installed in Wanford, if you have them, as a precaution. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

River levels are high on the River Roding in Abridge, Buckhurst Hill and Loughton because of the heavy rain over the weekend. There is a risk of flooding today, Tuesday 8th November, to gardens, roads and low lying land due to high river levels. 
Further rainfall is forecast today that will keep the river levels high all day.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and remain aware of the weather forecast. 
This message will be updated by 6pm today, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now started falling on the River Roding in the Molehill Green, Dunmow, Ongar, Fyfield, High Ongar and Stapleford following heavy rainfall yesterday, Sunday 6th November. The risk of flooding to roads and low-lying land is now reducing. 

Further light rainfall is forecast today, Monday 7th November and tomorrow, but we do not expect this to increase the risk of flooding. 

We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 

Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

The River Lox is still high, but is slowly falling. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the length of the river Lox. Recent showers Monday night and Tuesday morning could delay the river's return to normal until Wednesday afternoon. We predict river levels will continue to fall, however there remains uncertainty in the weather forecast, particularly around rainfall amounts and locations. Scattered heavy showers forecast for Tuesday and Wednesday, have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. Please continue to operate private water control structures in Brewhurst, to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar at Alverstone is higher than normal but it continues to slowly fall. Overnight only 4mm of rain was recorded at Wroxall. Showers, some heavy, are forecast later on today and tomorrow (Wednesday 9/11/22). Whilst these showers are likely to cause an increase in water level, it is currently unlikely that the totals forecast (10-20mm) will flood property. As we expect a continuation of minor impact flooding to road, land and possibly gardens, a Flood Alert will remain in force for the Eastern Yar over the next 24 hours. From Thursday (10/11/22) onwards, the weather is forecast to be dry and so the situation will finally improve towards the end of the week.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Further rainfall is forecast today, and levels may rise, but will remain below the alert threshold. The weather forecast for the remainder of the week is for dry weather.
We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely to continue into this evening. The River Colne has risen steadily in response to recent heavy rainfall from Sunday onwards, but is now stabilised and levels will slowly drop back over the course of Tuesday evening. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. it will take time for river levels to fall following the rain. The forecast is for further rain through today, Tuesday 8th November, but drier conditions for the rest of the week. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 4pm today, Tuesday 8th November.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high and very slowly rising near Shripney, Bersted and Felpham. Flood water will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and possibly parts of the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road and land at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Scattered heavy showers are forecast Tuesday and Wednesday, which have the potential to cause another small rise in river levels. If the showers miss West Sussex, the Aldingbourne Rife could begin to slowly fall in Bersted from Tuesday afternoon. However, river levels will be higher than normal all week. Only minimal or minor flood impacts are currently expected in Barnham, where river levels are already falling. Please keep flood protection products in place in Barnham as a precaution, if you have them. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

items.description: South Devon coast from Dawlish Warren to Seaton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Tuesday evening. High water at Exmouth is at 18:45 hours, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Force 6 South Westerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 1.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be up to 330mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level on Tuesday evening at Exmouth is 2.38 mAOD, this is 0.33 metres above the astronomical tide level.
The forecast tide level is now lowering. As the weather transitions to a more settled outlook over the next 24 hours, no further impacts are currently expected.
The forecast tide level and wave height are now lowering. As the weather transitions to a more settled outlook over the next 24 hours, no further impacts are currently expected.

floodArea.riverOrSea: The Solent, Portsmouth Harbour, Langstone Harbour

items.message: The forecast tide level is now lowering. As moderate wave heights are forecast this evening (Tuesday 8/11/22 at 23:00) spray overtopping impacting footpaths may occur along the southern coastal frontage at high tide tonight. After this time, the weather transitions to a more settled outlook and further impacts are not currently expected.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused rivers to rise and further intense showers are expected today. River levels are expected to remain high throughout the day and fall slowly overnight into Wednesday morning.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Dart has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. Whilst additional intense showers are possible on Tuesday, no further flooding is expected.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message:
Heavy rainfall overnight has caused rivers to rise and further intense showers are expected today. River levels are expected to remain high throughout the day and fall slowly overnight into Wednesday morning.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

The forecast is for strong winds, large waves and spray overtopping on the coast. 
We are expecting total water levels to be high for this evenings high tide. High water tonight will be at 18:25 pm, with force 6 south westerly winds. 
Areas most at risk include the inner harbour, East Beach and the esplanade on East Beach.
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We will continue to monitor the situation closely.
We will update this message by 12:00 PM on 09/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: Levels are now falling at the Beggearn Huish river gauge. Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and will re-issue this alert if necessary.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences and clearing debris from weed screens.  Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

The River Arun at Pulborough is high. In the last week, more than a month's rain (100mm) has been recorded at Hardham. Flooding could affect the A29 at Pulborough. Water will be extensive through fields and could affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. Water will be close to the tops of the banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. In Arundel, only minimal flood impacts are currently expected. Very little rain is forecast, but the river will continue to respond to the rainfall of recent days. The river has slowed in its rise, but could climb a little higher over the high tide period midday Tuesday. River levels will not return nearer to normal until next week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them, as a precaution. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 21:00 08/11/2022.

Flood Warning has been issued for Tuesday evening's tide at Preston Beach. Water levels will be higher than normal due to a spring tide, a tidal surge, strong winds and large waves.
High tide this evening (08/11/2022) at Preston Beach will be at 18:43 PM, with force 7 south westerly winds. Flooding is possible at the Sea Life Centre and the Preston Beach Road area of Lodmoor. Conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
We continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this warning if necessary.
This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 09/11/2022, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Dart from Buckfastleigh to Totnes, including Staverton
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Dart has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. Whilst additional intense showers are possible on Tuesday, no further flooding is expected.

Tuesday evening's tide at 23:00 on 08/11/2022 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with strong South Westerly Force 7 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.24 m. The total forecast tide is 4.99 metres Chart Datum (2.25 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. A very small amount of water might reach Bosham High Street. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. Minor flood impacts could occur over Wednesday morning's tide, peaking at 11:30 09/11/2022. It is currently thought Wednesday morning's tide will be a few centimetres lower than Tuesday morning's tide was. Less flood risk is expected from Thursday. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 09:00 on 09/11/2022.
